subject: OS-2647 add vminfod to keep track of VM state and speed up lookups in vmadm Reviewed by: Josh Wilsdon <josh@wilsdon.ca> Approved by: Angela Fong <angela.fong@joyent.com>
commitMessage:
OS-2647 add vminfod to keep track of VM state and speed up lookups in vmadm
Reviewed by: Josh Wilsdon <josh@wilsdon.ca>
Approved by: Angela Fong <angela.fong@joyent.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1: CI-Testing+1

"make check" passed ok

Patch Set 1:

A couple of review notes:

1. node-vasync is updated to the latest version with this change, as well as with node-vasync#37 integrated.  Once this change is merged (https://github.com/joyent/node-vasync/issues/37, https://cr.joyent.us/#/c/2398/) these files can be removed from this vminfod review to make it simpler.

2. vm-agent requires a vminfod watcher (see https://devhub.joyent.com/jira/browse/AGENT-979, https://cr.joyent.us/#/c/2730/).  However, that implementation currently uses `vminfod/client` from this CR.  The problem with that is vminfod/client is shipped with the platform, and as such, can cause issues when called from an unexpected version of node.

If you'd like to review this code, please not these above 2 issues that will likely result in changes to this CR.

Change has been successfully merged by Dave Eddy
You probably want to add 'fswatcher: CPPFLAGS += -D_LARGEFILE_SOURCE -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64' similar to vmbundle -- otherwise fswatcher may crash if given a largefile to watch
Could we be explicit and add = DEFAULTMUTEX (or ERRORCHECKMUTEX)?
Done
I'd just go ahead and use the fnvlist_ versions everywhere -- if it does abort w/ ENOMEM, it'd be good to have a core just in case it's due to a memory leak and not low system memory.
See the comment here for an explanation of why ENSURE0 is used https://cr.joyent.us/#/c/1484/6/src/sysevent.c@48
If built as a 64-bit binary, struct timeval's members will be 64-bit -- it might be better to go ahead and use 64-bit ints here -- zfs (and ls) already use 2 uint64_t's for crtime for example.
The problem is that this C program exists as a helper program for fswatcher.js... JavaScript won't be able to properly handle 64 bit integers as far as I know.
calloc would be better here -- it'll do an overflow check on the product
Done
Nit: `EXIT_FAILURE` could be used instead of 1

I personally prefer to explicitly use numbers for exit codes since this program will be executed from within JavaScript.  This way, though not currently the case, the JavaScript could check the exit code and look for specific failure cases.

However, since the JavaScript pretty much just aborts on *any* failure, if you feel strongly about it I can use EXIT_FAILURE.

It's mostly just convention in case you wanted to use that -- in theory some value other than 1 could be used on some system to denote failure.  In practice, if it hasn't changed in ~30-40 years it seems unlikely it'll change anytime soon :), so if you want to leave as is, that's fine with me.
Minor nit, but I'm not sure if there's any point in distinguishing between these cases and 'default' -- you're aborting either way.

True, this is just a way of explicitly stating that these errors (EFAULT, EIO, ENAMETOOLONG, etc.) are accounted for and should abort the process, and are not simply ignored or forgotten by the programmer.
VERIFY3S might be preferable here -- if the test fails, it'll print both values in the abort msg
Done
Consider VERIFY3S as above
Done
Nit: `EXIT_FAILURE` could be used here instead.

the lifetime of this allocation is slightly confusing (I see that it gets free()d in the destroy_handle() call. maybe that's worth a comment ? (the args for check_and_rearm_event() are what makes this confusing to me, I think).

I'll add a comment.  I'll need to refresh my own memory, but I know when creating the watch with event ports and not duplicating the name, it was possible that the next file being watched would overwrite the original file... i'll figure this out and add a comment.
Nit: `EXIT_FAILURE` could be used here instead.
Is this to silence an unused parameter warning?  If so, you can use 'void *arg __unused' to suppress the warning.
ah perfect, ty!

EXIT_FAILURE as above -- also err(3C) should already append 'strerror(errno)' to the string passed in the argument (after formatting).

Also, have you verified what happens if stdin is just closed?  I think fgets() returns NULL, but I'm not sure that errno gets set -- you may need to call feof(3C) to determine that (and display a sensible error message).

Ah, good call!

 # echo -n | ./fswatcher 
 fswatcher: fswatcher: error on stdin (errno: 0): Error 0
 : Error 0

That's a pretty lame error message - I'll clean this up.
Same as above.
Done
EXIT_FAILURE as above, though perhaps perror + abort() since this shouldn't happen + would we want a core in this case?
Good call, this shouldn't happen... so if it does it should abort().
Maybe just use err(3C) like in other functions?
+1, not sure how this snuck in there... most likely this had been written first before i switched over to err(3C).

I'm confused by the intermixed use of pthread and thr functions here.

if we're joining these, should we use pthread_join() and for locks pthread_mutex_lock() ?

Or perhaps thr_create() here (and leave the rest alone) ?
This is just my lack of experience programming in C with threading - i'll rewrite this to use `thr_create()` to be consistent.
remove (see below)
Done
since you've settled on the non-pthread versions, change this to thread_t and then you're pthread free (and can remove the header include directive).
Will do, ty.

Apologies for not catching this on the first pass, but probably should check and error if the threads don't get created (it's rare, but can happen either due to resource controls or if segkpm (I think, one of them) is exhausted.
Will do.

I think to match vmadm, we should change this so that the executable itself is in /usr/vm/sbin and if there's a link it's from /usr/sbin/vminfod. Also: what do you think about renaming the cli tool "vminfo" to distinguish it from the daemon vminfod?
Agreed on both points... will change.
See my comment in Makefile, I think this should be in /usr/vm/sbin instead.
Done
Done
Done
Why do we no longer need to care here about ECONNREFUSED, and trying to reconnect?
oh no, this must have somehow gotten lost from OS-5999 during a merge from master.  I'll review this file and figure out how to get all of that logic back in here.
"also *apply* to routes", though I realize that's not your bug. :)
ha, good catch - will fix as well.
I think this -r text might be confusing. Specifically: my first thought at seeing this was: how does it make sense to ever output events when the events are *not* ready?

hm, do you know how I could reword it? when `-r` is supplied, a special event is emitted when the stream is ready, ie.


 [root@headnode (emy-12) /usr/vm]# vmadm events -r
 [18:15:24.610Z] ready
 [18:15:25.362Z] 31400151 sdcdockertest_affinity_b9ce... modify: 
 zone_state changed :: "installed" -> "incomplete"


Without `-r`, that "ready" line won't be printed and the event stream will start *sometime after* the command is successfully forked and exec'd.

I think your description in your comment sounds good. :) Indicating that it's a special/extra event when the stream is ready would make this more clear. Even just adding the word "extra" after "Output an" would make this clearer to me I think.
Done
I wonder if naming this cancelFn (and everywhere else cancel() is used) would make it more obvious that it's a function here?
Agreed - will change.
again, consider cancelFn?
Done

It's possible to do a single:

    zfs set prop1=value1 prop2=value2 dataset

is there a reason not to do that here? Is that so we can know which one failed without reading the stderr?

That was the reasoning I had used actually - I'd want the failure to be obvious if a command failed.  I could rewrite this to all be one command but I don't think it's strictly necessary.  Also, the vminfod stream is reused so we don't have to worry about creating and tearing that down every command.
Ok, so maybe just a comment then just indicating that these are set separately in order to make it clearer which one failed?
Done
same here, and I'm going to stop pointing these out. The comment obviously applies to all cases. :)
Done
when doing these in parallel, are we guaranteed that the watcher will be ready before the makeIndestructible() does its business in all cases?

So that's an interesting point.  watchForEvent is synchronous, in that the watcher is already created, and the call to watchForEvent just attaches a listener.  The only way this could break is if vasync.parallel for some reason decided to run the second function first... I actually don't know if parallel guarantees it'll run them in order.
Might be worth checking, or at least documenting that this is the assumption.
https://github.com/joyent/node-vasync/issues/38
Based on dap's comment there, should we change where we're using this pattern to using barriers?

I have to look into this more.  Converting this pattern to use barriers will require a lot more boilerplate code, specifically around manually handling errors from either the vminfod blocking code, or the code itself to do work (in this case, makeIndestructible).  I may be able to abstract this logic into a function specifically for the vminfod work case, but I don't know yet. I'll check this out.
... because it was already empty, right?
correct.
will add more descriptive comment about "shouldBlock"

Where did this come from?

And what happens when there's no /usr/bin/sleep? Or that doesn't support an "Inf" argument?

Also I think the comment here might be confusing since sleep != halt for a zone.

Oh wow... this is old and actually might not be relevant anymore - this came from the time where short-lived vms were causing issues - but that should be fixed now.  I'll do some testing and see if it's necessary anymore.

:D get ready.

I *may* or *may not* be able to da that. How do I know this? I got absolutely screwed by it.

This is not a vasync.pipeline, but instead is a vasync.waterfall.  This means the results passed to the callback are propagated to the function below it.  *THIS MEANS*, the positional argument of the callback function *can change* based on how the callback above it was invoked.  Right or wrong, I'm trying to be very explicit here to avoid any weirdness from that.  Perhaps this can be changed from waterfall? I haven't looked too closely into it but I will now.
Sure, what's here is fine then.

Under what circumstances would this "retry" ever work? Especially given that there's little to no delay between the ready event and us doing this VM.load, it seems surprising to me that without a bug this would happen. Is this here in order to detect a bug in vminfod? If so, should we blow up or at least warn that it wasn't there initially, but was on the VM.load?

This was me being lazy and not forming my own error message.  But in reality, because of how much we need to rely on vminfod, I should removed this whole VM.load section and just use the VM found in vminfod, and throw an error if it is not found.
That sounds reasonable.

Why do we no longer need to lock here? I see that writeAllMetadata now does locking itself, but that lock is not around the load and increment here which seems like it could cause problems. If two things tried to update at once, for any reason the value will not be incremented twice. If two things tried to set the restartdelay at once, one of the updates would be lost. etc.

If we're assuming this is safe because we know all the callers and know that there's never going to be a case where two updates happen at once, that should be called out clearly to ensure nothing else tries to use this function as it would be dangerous to do so.
hm, yes that is a bug.  I'll fix the locking here.

Is there a reason for switching here to parseInt instead of Number?

I think instead of replacing one with the other (they're both bad in different ways), if we're going to replace with anything we should switch to using:

https://github.com/joyent/node-jsprim#parseintegerstr-options
I always prefer parseInt because you can specify the base (base 10) to avoid any weirdness with octals.  I can replace this with jsprim.
It's fine to make this a followup ticket I think.
Same question as above: when could this happen?
same as above.
*to* block for?
yes, good catch.
proptable.js?
I'll use that.
I don't see that code was added to use these from proptable.js, am I missing something?
If this isn't going to be done now, should we create a ticket for it and point to that here?
oh, i missed this.  I'll make that change now.
Again: I don't see that this was done?

While not an error, I find that defining variables in the middle of their scope like this (and elsewhere in this file) has a tendency to eventually cause problems (it's similar to using global variables all over in bash). Luckily these are usually caught by the linter when they happen, but still I recommend in general moving all variables to the top of their scope rather than sprinkling them around all over the scope. Not something that I'd block the change over, but something to think about.
I'll make the change.
Isn't this still sending as stdin via the opts.stdin below?
hm, it is. not sure how that happened.  will update.

The purpose of prettyPath is to be printable/human readable, I wonder if the name could reflect that more somehow? humanPath. strPath, printablePath? I don't know. I'm just not sure prettyPath is the most obvious name if one runs across it, and since it appears in the output of `vmadm events` it seems once this is released we'll be stuck with it. I wonder if others have opinions here.

Personally, when I see "pretty" I assume that it isn't meant for to be used programmatically, or that if I do use it it is subject to change or not fully consistent.  I wouldn't be against changing the keyname though if others have opinions on this.
The to/from naming here seems like it's not so obvious what it means when we're talking about added/removed... I wonder if "old"/"new" would make more sense? Just a thought.
Ah, I can see that - especially in the codebase here we consider it A vs B.  "old"/"new" is a change i'd be happy to make.
s/tha/the/
Done

If for some reason fswatcher.c is streaming out events faster than we can read them (for example, if node's busy with other work), how could that  be detected? Could we look at the time value in the stream messages and keep the average delta between that and the current time for the last 10, 100 and 1000 messages or something like that? Just a thought.

I suppose this is definitely possible - basically you want a way to detect if the delta is larger than some acceptable value averaged over the last X messages AFAICT.  I'll try something like that and see.
Any results to report?
Will be in the next patchset

In milliseconds, we have:


 [root@headnode (emy-12) ~]# vminfo status -f | json fswatcher.message_delays
 {
   "1": 0,
   "10": 0,
   "100": 0,
   "1000": 0.008
 }


When under heavy load (typically during a test run where multiple VMs are being modified at the same time)

 [2018-02-28T21:36:39.836Z]  WARN: vminfod/4423 on headnode: message took 47ms to process (> 10ms) (deltaMs=47)
     avg: {
       "1": 47,
       "10": 4.8,
       "100": 1.56,
       "1000": 1.145
     }

The last 1 messages is the single message that took 47ms... the last 10 messages are ~4.8ms which pretty much means that the 47ms message is the outlier.  Interesting stats to see definitely.
10 seconds, not 5 I think?
Good catch - it was 5 before Isaac started roughing up vminfod with his crazy tests ha.
Does "Date" need to be a special case here given that this is also the default case? Would https://github.com/joyent/node-jsprim#deepcopyobj also work here?
Unfortunately yes, because typeof a date object returns 'object'.  I'll look into pulling jsprim into the platform.
Ah, cool.
The default value for restart_init should be true.
Done
s/minuto/minute/
HA - good catch.

Is it possible for an even to be too large for a single read such that you'd do a vs.read and get only part of an event? If not, what prevents that? If so, should the example include code to handle this?

Conversely, if we always read a whole event object, how does this behave if a VM has a 10M blob added to its metadata?

I don't actually know.  The stream is set with objectMode: true so I don't *think* so.  The data is taken and piped to a node-lstream first so that should buffer up all of the data until a full object can be constructed.  Also, I have no idea what would happen if the JSON blob got huge - it probably wouldn't be good.
Should this be vw.vms and vw.vm?
yes, good catch.
Could we set an error code instead and check for either the message or code?
I'm not sure I understand what you mean?  Perhaps just leave the code as 404 and check that in VM.js?

I meant, set an error code here on the err we're returning and have the code that's currently calling this and expecting to see "No such zone configured" message check either for the message or the code. If that's too much hassle, that's fine.

Is it the client's responsibility to reconnect in this case I assume? If so, maybe what a client should do should be called out in the block comment at the top of the file? Is reconnecting immediately the best choice? I assume one case here is if the vminfod service crashes or otherwise restarts while a client is streaming... Hopefully those are not common cases, but for correctness we should make sure clients handling that.

Right now there is 0 handling for that as the daemon *should* never crash.  If it does currently, pretty much everything relying on it goes down with it.

What do you think the proper way to handle the daemon dying is?

To me, it would seem that we'd want to retry but perhaps some sort of backoff? I don't know what point we'd want to give up... Probably never because there's no clearly correct thing to do. If the daemon crashes and all clients are hung waiting on it, hopefully that'll make it very obvious quickly what the problem is.

Since this is not part of the API and not used outside this file, maybe use the name _exhaustEvents to indicate that it's not something that should be used? I'm not sure "exhaust" is the best name here either. Perhaps consider _clearEvents?
Agreed with both of these, thanks.
I think "readable" is a confusing name here. Perhaps processEvents?
Done
Is there a reason most multi-word functions are using camelCase but this one is not? processChange below for example or watchForChanges above make me think this would be called processEvent.
So, the *actual* reason is I probably wrote `processevent` a year or two ago when I wasn't using the standard camelCase'ing :p.  I'll change it to be consistent.

Suggestion: using the name "expectedChange" instead of "change" here might make it clearer what's going on. It's otherwise not obvious what the difference between a change or an event is until one reads the whole block comment here and even then I had to double-check that my understanding was correct and things weren't just accidentally misnamed here.
OK, i'll rename the changes so it's clear what we "want" vs what we actually received.
This is another place where it seems like it would be good to move the variable declaration to the top of their scope to limit confusion.
If only JavaScript had some good way to break out of a `forEach`....  Agreed, i'll make the change.

Does this mean that if vminfod is restarted, the last_modified can go backward? I wonder if that causes problems for anything.

The only way I can think to work around this would be to "touch" the xml file whenever we bump the last_modified, so that on startup when we first load the VM we'll start with the same last_modified as we had before.
Any further thoughts here?

I have removed all of the `last_modified` logic from vminfod completely - it will no longer be a special value that is modified manually by the daemon.  Instead, vminfod will just pull the value from the vmload logic.
Have you seen this happen in your testing?

Yes.  I have seen the cache objects are different, but i have NEVER seen the vmobjs generated as a result of the cache objects being different.

Basically, if the system is being used (like during the test suite running), it's possible that the full load will show some ZFS snapshots that weren't seen by vminfod (i'm not sure why yet, this is very rare).  However, there is no changes to the actual vmobj blobs as a result. 


 vminfo status -f  | json refresh_errors refresh_log


refresh_errors hold any error messages from vminfod failing to do a full refresh and refresh_log shows any refreshes that resulted in the cache or the vmobjects being different.
How long does this typically take?
~5s on emy-12... this could take minutes though (when Isaac was testing).  It grows with the number of VMs

It might be worth creating a ticket (not to be done now) for exposing this data using artedi as well so that it can be monitored with our monitoring systems to detect problems.

Since the data's already here, that should be pretty simple.

Looking at this data on a live system, it looks like it's going to be really helpful!
It looks like this function fails to call cb2, and instead calls cb. That seems like a bug. Does that mean the next function here in the pipeline is never run by any tests?
This *has* to be a bug - there's no way I intended this.
I think "teardown" here might be misleading. We're just removing the object from the cache, right?

ha, this comment predates me https://github.com/joyent/smartos-live/blob/OS-2647/src/vm/node_modules/vmevent/vminfo.js#L419


I'll remove it.
thanks!
There's already an isUUID function in src/vm/node_modules/utils.js, is there some reason not to use that one?
ah, will use that instead.
once again it would be nice imo to declare variables at the top of their scope rather than hidden in some nesting. But Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯
I can do that.

fyi: I think you could also use assert.ifError(err) here. If you:

    var assert = require('assert-plus');
cool, will do - this is just the same logic that's already there but i'll make the change.

yes.

So, my intention wasn't to reformat everything like that, but it just so happened as I was testing over the months I found it easier to follow the flow of the code like that, and also avoid and weird possibilities of double callbacks.

Basically, the diff on this CR will sometimes make it look like i *only* reformatted sections to look like that, when in reality they've gone through many iterations and had been rewritten only to be un-rewritten :p.  But yes, I prefer that style and it cuts down on a level of indentation so I'll change it.
